###*Here you'll find resources that we've collected to help you on your mindfulness journey.*

<br>


###I want to...

<br>

###download an app
There are many apps to choose from. Here are some of our favourites...

Most apps are free to download from your app store and offer a free trial, whereas some ask you to buy the app first with no subscription required.

*   Headspace (iOS + Android)

*   Calm (iOS + Android)

*   Buddhify (iOS + Android)

<br>
<br>

###learn more about the background of mindfulness

One of our students recommended the following course for anyone interested in getting to know more about the history and philosophy behind mindfulness:
[Demystifying mindfulness online course at Coursera](https://www.coursera.org/learn/mindfulness)

<br>
<br>

###learn about the science behind mindfulness

Here are some great videos that explain some of the scientific underpinnings behind mindfulness.

*TW: can refer to depression, trauma and suicidal thoughts*

<br>

*   [ASAP Science video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Aw71zanwMnY) overviewing the effects of meditation on the brain, biology and behaviour. An excellent and accessible overview!

*   Dr. Shauna Shapiro's [TedTalk](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IeblJdB2-Vo) on her journey into mindfunless, her work on the mechanisms behind mindfulness and the application of mindfulness research.

*   Prof. Mark Williams on the [Neuroscience of Mindfulness](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8GVwnxkWmSM).

<br>
<br>

###find out about related organisations

[Oxford Mindfulness Centre](http://oxfordmindfulness.org/)


<br>
<br>

###read some books about mindfulness
A general good place to start is with any introductory or beginners book. This may seem obvious but it's good to remind ourselves that we won't become advanced overnight!

*   Great instroductory books include **"Mindfulness: A practical guide to finding peace in a frantic world"** by Prof. Mark Williams and Dr. Danny Penman.

*   For a read about integrating mindfulness into daily life, we'd recommend **"This is happening"** by Rohan Gunatillake.

*   Wanting an overview of the science? Check out **"The Science of Meditation"** by Daniel Goleman and Richard Davidson.

<br>
<br>

###read the articles that you have cited
Here's our reference list. As we add more content and include more research on mindfulness, our reference list will continue to grow - so keep your eyes peeled!

*   Baer, R. A., Smith, G. T., Hopkins, J., Krietemeyer, J., & Toney, L. (2006). Using self-report assessment methods to explore facets of mindfulness. *Assessment*, 13(1), 27-45.

*   Black, D. S. (2011). A brief definition of mindfulness. *Behavioral Neuroscience*, 7(2), 109.

*   Brown, K. W., & Ryan, R. M. (2003). The benefits of being present: mindfulness and its role in psychological well-being. *Journal of personality and social psychology*, 84(4), 822.

*   Cavanagh, K., Strauss, C., Cicconi, F., Griffiths, N., Wyper, A., & Jones, F. (2013). A randomised controlled trial of a brief online mindfulness-based intervention. *Behaviour research and therapy*, 51(9), 573-578.

*   de Vibe, M., Solhaug, I., Tyssen, R., Friborg, O., Rosenvinge, J. H., Sørlie, T., ... & Bjørndal, A. (2015). Does personality moderate the effects of mindfulness training for medical and psychology students?. *Mindfulness*, 6(2), 281-289.

*   Greeson, J. M., Juberg, M. K., Maytan, M., James, K., & Rogers, H. (2014). A randomized controlled trial of Koru: a mindfulness program for college students and other emerging adults. *Journal of American College Health*, 62(4), 222-233.

*   Kabat-Zinn, J. (1994) *Wherever you go, there you are: Mindfulness meditation in everyday life.* New York: Hyperion Books.

*   Kerrigan, D., Chau, V., King, M., Holman, E., Joffe, A., & Sibinga, E. (2017). There is no performance, there is just this moment: the role of mindfulness instruction in promoting health and well-being among students at a highly-ranked university in the united states. *Journal of Evidence-Based Complementary & Alternative Medicine*, 22(4), 909-918.

*   Langer, E. J., & Moldoveanu, M. (2000). The construct of mindfulness. *Journal of social issues*, 56(1), 1-9.

*   Miller, C. J., Borsatto, J., & Al-Salom, P. (2018). Testing a quick mindfulness intervention in the university classroom. *Journal of Further and Higher Education*, 1-9.

*   National Union of Students (2016). Mental Health Poll. Retrieved from: http://appg-students.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/Mental-Health-Poll-November-15-Summary.pdf Accessed: 14/11/2018
  *   For an overview of the report in the context of student wellbeing issues, see this [report](https://www.nus.org.uk/PageFiles/2161132/APPG%20on%20Students%20-%20December%20-%20Speaker%20briefing%20-%20Mental%20Health%20(002).pdf) by the All Party Parliamentary Group on Students.

*   Papies, E. K., Barsalou, L. W., & Custers, R. (2012). Mindful attention prevents mindless impulses. *Social Psychological and Personality Science*, 3(3), 291-299.

*   Solhaug, I., Eriksen, T. E., de Vibe, M., Haavind, H., Friborg, O., Sørlie, T., & Rosenvinge, J. H. (2016). Medical and psychology student’s experiences in learning mindfulness: Benefits, paradoxes, and pitfalls. *Mindfulness*, 7(4), 838-850.

*   Tan, J., Lo, P., Ge, N., & Chu, C. (2016). Self-esteem mediates the relationship between mindfulness and social anxiety among Chinese undergraduate students. *Social Behavior and Personality: an international journal*, 44(8), 1297-1304.
